awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields. 

This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal that will address aspects of quantum science and technology relevant to quantum sensing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum mechanics forms the foundation for much of our physical world. It explains why atomic energy levels are stable, why atoms bind together to form molecules, and the properties of materials such as heat capacity and conductivity. Remarkably, as quantum systems extend to even modestly larger size, the complexity of the system grows exponentially. For example, a quantum processor of even modest size has a parameter space that is larger than the number of particles in the observable universe. As a field, we are at a point where we can fabricate and control quantum systems with a complexity that would take millennia to capture with even the most powerful supercomputers.  In the coming years, control over this quantum complexity will dominate technological advances across all scientific disciplines; we only need to develop techniques to harness the advantages of quantum systems for advances in sensing, computation, and simulation.  

This grant supported the conceptualization of questions and research opportunities that strive to harness quantum advantages across three frontiers of research. These include: "looking out" - where quantum technologies are harnessed to advance the fields of astrophysics, "looking in" - the application of quantum technologies for imaging the microscopic environment, and "looking where we cannot yet see" - including searches for physics beyond the standard model, new probes of many-body order, and new ways to harness the exponential complexity of quantum systems for sensing.

Over 50 scientists across disciplines including physics, math, biology, chemistry, engineering, computer science, materials, and medicine participated in guided multi-week discussions and brainstorming. Together, the group identified new scientific opportunities and formed enduring collaborations.
